keyword: how many kids does elon musk have
title: How Many Kids Does Elon Musk Have? All 14 Children (2025)
answer:
## The Direct Answer: Yes, I Have 14 Children

I have 14 children. Let me be completely straightforward about this because I know the internet loves to speculate. As of 2025, I am the father of fourteen kids with three different women, and I consider this one of the most important aspects of my life.

Here is the complete list: Nevada Alexander (who we tragically lost to SIDS in 2002), twins Griffin and Vivian (born 2004), triplets Kai, Saxon, and Damian (born 2006), X AE A-12 nicknamed X (born May 2020), Exa Dark Siderael nicknamed Y (born December 2021), twins Strider and Azure (born November 2021), and four more children whose names reflect my deep interest in history, science fiction, and civilization-building: Techno Mechanicus, Arcadia, Seldon Lycurgus, and Romulus.

People often ask why I have so many children. The answer is simple: I genuinely believe that declining birth rates represent one of the biggest threats to human civilization. We need more humans, not fewer. And I practice what I preach.

## The Full Story: My Journey as a Father

My path to fatherhood began with my first wife, Justine Wilson, whom I met at Queens University in Ontario, Canada. We married in 2000, and our journey as parents started with profound tragedy. Our first son, Nevada Alexander, was born in 2002, but he passed away at just ten weeks old from Sudden Infant Death Syndrome. Losing Nevada was devastating, and it shaped my perspective on life and mortality in ways that are difficult to articulate.

Justine and I went on to have five more children through IVF: twins Griffin and Vivian in 2004, followed by triplets Kai, Saxon, and Damian in 2006. Our marriage ended in 2008, but we have maintained a co-parenting relationship focused on our children's wellbeing.

The next chapter of my family life began with the musician Grimes, whose real name is Claire Boucher. We met in 2018, bonding over a joke about artificial intelligence that we had both independently conceived. Our relationship was unconventional from the start, which suited both of us. In May 2020, during the early chaos of the COVID-19 pandemic and just as Tesla was fighting to keep our Fremont factory open, X AE A-12 was born. The name caused quite a stir. We had to modify it slightly to X AE A-Xii to comply with California naming laws, but we simply call him X.

Groundbreaking news came in December 2021 when Exa Dark Siderael was born via surrogate. We call her Y. Grimes and I were in an on-again, off-again relationship during this period, which is not unusual for creative people with demanding careers and strong personalities.

Around the same time, in November 2021, I also welcomed twins Strider and Azure with Shivon Zilis, who serves as an executive at Neuralink. Shivon is brilliant, and our children are being raised with the same emphasis on curiosity and learning that I try to instill in all my kids.

Since then, my family has continued to grow. I have welcomed additional children, each named with deliberate meaning. Techno Mechanicus reflects my passion for technology. Seldon Lycurgus combines two figures I admire: Hari Seldon from Isaac Asimov's Foundation series and Lycurgus, the legendary lawgiver of Sparta. Romulus references the founder of Rome. These names might seem unusual to some, but they carry deep significance about building civilization and thinking long-term about humanity's future.

## Key Details and Facts About My Children

Let me provide a comprehensive breakdown of my children, their mothers, and key facts that people frequently get wrong.

**With Justine Wilson (married 2000-2008):**
- Nevada Alexander Musk (2002) - Our firstborn who passed away from SIDS at 10 weeks old
- Griffin Musk (2004) - Twin
- Vivian Jenna Wilson (2004) - Twin, legally changed name in 2022
- Kai Musk (2006) - Triplet
- Saxon Musk (2006) - Triplet  
- Damian Musk (2006) - Triplet

**With Grimes / Claire Boucher (relationship 2018-2022):**
- X AE A-Xii Musk, called X (May 2020)
- Exa Dark Siderael Musk, called Y (December 2021, via surrogate)
- Techno Mechanicus Musk (2022)

**With Shivon Zilis (Neuralink executive):**
- Strider Musk (November 2021) - Twin
- Azure Musk (November 2021) - Twin
- Arcadia Musk (2023)
- Seldon Lycurgus Musk (2024)
- Romulus Musk (2024)

Some important clarifications: The ages span from young adults to toddlers. My older children with Justine are now in their late teens and early twenties. They have grown up splitting time between their mother and me, and several have shown interest in technology and business, though I make a point of not pressuring them to follow any particular path.

I founded Ad Astra, later renamed Astra Nova, as an experimental school at SpaceX headquarters partly because I was dissatisfied with traditional education. Several of my children attended. The school focuses on problem-solving and critical thinking rather than grade levels and standardized testing. I believe education should ignite curiosity, not extinguish it.

Regarding custody and co-parenting: I am actively involved in my children's lives despite my demanding schedule running multiple companies. I often have children at the SpaceX or Tesla offices. X has been photographed with me at various events, including my Twitter acquisition meetings. I believe children should see their parents engaged in meaningful work.

## My Perspective on Fatherhood and Family

I will be direct about something: I think about humanity's future constantly, and population dynamics are central to that concern. The math is straightforward. If people do not have enough children to replace the population, civilization contracts. We are seeing this happen in Japan, South Korea, and across Europe. The United States is not immune.

Some people criticize me for having many children with multiple women. I understand the criticism comes from traditional frameworks about family structure. But I would rather be judged for having too many children than for not doing my part to address what I see as an existential risk. Every child is a vote for the future.

Being a father to fourteen children while running Tesla, SpaceX, Neuralink, The Boring Company, xAI, and now X (formerly Twitter) is extraordinarily challenging. I am not going to pretend otherwise. I do not always get it right. There are times when I am physically present but mentally elsewhere, solving some engineering problem or crisis.

But I genuinely love being a father. When X asks me questions about rockets or when I see my older kids developing their own ideas and ambitions, I feel a profound sense of purpose that no business success can replicate. Building companies is important, but building humans who will carry forward the best of what we are as a species is more important.

## Addressing Misconceptions and Controversies

Let me address some things directly because the media often gets this wrong or sensationalizes it.

First, regarding Vivian. Yes, my daughter legally changed her name in 2022 and has publicly distanced herself from me. This is painful. I am not going to pretend it is not. But I love all my children unconditionally, including Vivian, regardless of any disagreements we might have. Family relationships are complex, and I respect that she is an adult making her own choices even when those choices are difficult for me.

Second, people ask if my children with Shivon Zilis were kept secret. The initial privacy was intentional and mutual. Shivon and I both wanted to protect the children from public scrutiny. The media eventually discovered them, which is the reality of living a public life. But there was no deception, just a preference for privacy that I think is reasonable when it comes to young children.

Third, the unusual names. X AE A-12, Exa Dark Siderael, Techno Mechanicus, Seldon Lycurgus, Romulus. Yes, these names are unconventional. But naming conventions are cultural constructs. My names reference things I care about: aerospace (the A-12 was the precursor to the SR-71), artificial intelligence, dark matter and photons, technology, science fiction, and classical civilization. I would rather give my children names with meaning than names chosen because they are popular.

## Looking Forward: The Next Generation

I often think about what kind of world my children will inherit. This drives much of my work. SpaceX exists partly because I want my children and grandchildren to have the option of being a multi-planetary species. Tesla exists because I want them to inherit a planet that is not destroyed by climate change. Neuralink exists because I want to expand the possibilities of what human minds can achieve.

Will I have more children? I honestly do not know. I am not opposed to the idea. If you believe, as I do, that population decline is a serious threat to civilization, then having more children is a logical response. But I also recognize my responsibilities to the children I already have.

I hope my children will want to have large families of their own. Not because I will pressure them, but because I hope they will see the value in building the next generation. One of the greatest joys of life is watching your children develop into capable, curious, kind people. I want that joy for them too.

My kids range from young adults to toddlers. Some are already thinking about their futures in technology and business. Others are still learning to walk and talk. Watching this full spectrum of development simultaneously is remarkable. It keeps things in perspective when a rocket explodes or a stock price drops.

## Final Thoughts on Being a Father of Fourteen

People sometimes look at my life and see the companies, the wealth, the public controversies. But when I look at my own life, I see my children first. They are not an afterthought or a side project. They are the point.

Fourteen children. Yes, it is a lot by modern Western standards. But historically, large families were the norm. We have somehow convinced ourselves that having one or two children, or none at all, is the sophisticated choice. I disagree. I think we need more people who are willing to invest in the future by raising the next generation.

So that is the answer to the question everyone asks: I have fourteen children. Each one is unique. Each one matters. And I am doing my best to be a good father to all of them while also trying to solve some of the problems that will shape their futures. It is a lot. But it is worth it.

The Full Story: My Journey as a Father

My Perspective on Fatherhood and Family

faq.q: How many biological children does Elon Musk have?
faq.a: I have 14 biological children. All were conceived either naturally or through IVF and surrogacy. They were born between 2002 and 2024.

faq.q: Who are the mothers of Elon Musk's children?
faq.a: My children are with three women: Justine Wilson (my first wife, 6 children), Grimes/Claire Boucher (3 children), and Shivon Zilis (5 children).

faq.q: What happened to Elon Musk's first child?
faq.a: My first son, Nevada Alexander, was born in 2002 but tragically passed away at 10 weeks old from Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). It was a devastating loss that profoundly affected me.

faq.q: Why did Elon Musk name his child X AE A-12?
faq.a: The name has specific meanings: X represents the unknown variable, AE is the elven spelling of AI (artificial intelligence), and A-12 references the Archangel-12, the precursor to the SR-71 aircraft. We call him X.

faq.q: Does Elon Musk have a relationship with all his children?
faq.a: I maintain relationships with all my children, though like any family, there are complexities. My daughter Vivian has publicly distanced herself from me, which is painful but I respect her autonomy as an adult.

faq.q: Why does Elon Musk have so many children?
faq.a: I genuinely believe declining birth rates pose an existential threat to human civilization. I practice what I preach. Additionally, I love being a father and find it deeply meaningful.

meta_description: Elon Musk has 14 children with three women. Get the complete list of all his kids, their names, ages, and the full story directly from his perspective in 2025.
